Context:
The Centre for Business at George Brown College offers an International Business Management program which is part of the School of Management. Students in this program are required to bring their own laptops due to a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) initiative. The Library Learning Commons provides open access computers and equipment that can be borrowed on a short-term basis.

Graduates of this program may pursue various careers in international business management such as export control analyst, junior import coordinator, logistics coordinator, logistics and customs coordinator, and customs rater. Students may also choose to pursue industry designations/certifications from the Federation of International Trade Training (FITT), Canadian Society of Customs Brokers (CSCB), and the Federation of International Freight Forwarding Associations (CIFFA).

George Brown College has an accredited educational partnership agreement with FITT to offer the FITT skills program. The requirements for each designation/certification are set by the granting body, not George Brown College. Students need to follow the process and meet all requirements on each respective website to qualify.

Entities: Centre for Business, School of Management, George Brown College, Bring Your Own Device (BYOD), Library Learning Commons, FITT, Canadian Society of Customs Brokers (CSCB), Federation of International Freight Forwarding Associations (CIFFA)

Graduates may pursue careers in various roles such as export control analyst, junior import coordinator, logistics coordinator, logistics and customs coordinator, and customs rater. Students can choose to pursue industry designations/certifications from FITT, CSCB, and CIFFA. George Brown College has an accredited educational partnership agreement with FITT to offer the FITT skills program. The requirements for each designation/certification are set by the granting body, not George Brown College.

Context:
The Forum for International Trade Training (FITT) offers the B411 program which requires completion of 13 mandatory courses. These courses are spread over two semesters.

Semester 1:
- BUS 4091: Global Trade Assessment, no prerequisite
- BUS 4092: International Sales and Marketing, no prerequisite
- BUS 4093: Supply Chain Management, no prerequisite
- BUS 4094: International Market Entry Strategies, no prerequisite
- BUS 4074: Accounting and Finance, no prerequisite
- BUS 4077: Global Leadership, no prerequisite
- BUS 4034: International Trade Finance (requires completion of BUS 4091)
- BUS 4037: International Trade Management (requires completion of BUS 4094)
- BUS 4042: Freight Forwarding (requires completion of BUS 4093)
- BUS 4076: Customs Administration (requires completion of BUS 4091)
- Capstone Project (requires successful completion of Semester 1)
- BUS 4079: International Business Speakers Series, no prerequisite

Semester 2:
- BUS 4096: Capstone Project, requires successful completion of Semester 1

The graduate from this program is expected to demonstrate the ability to conduct an environmental scan, market research, manage document preparation and procedures in global supply chains, evaluate statutory and regulatory compliance, develop marketing plans, identify relevant international financial documents, and negotiate effectively across cultures.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/International Business Management Program (Postgraduate) B411 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The text provides information on a program offered by George Brown College. The program focuses on analyzing and implementing integrative trade initiatives, developing international business plans, managing team projects, recommending strategies for corporate sustainability and ethics, and applying current technologies. The tuition fees are listed as $5,168.00 for domestic students and $17,826.00 for international students for the first two semesters starting in Fall 2022. The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria. Admission requirements include a college advanced diploma or bachelor's degree or relevant work experience, and English language proficiency testing. The text also mentions the availability of course exemptions and a transfer guide for students with previous college or university credits. For more information on international fees and admissions, applicants are encouraged to visit specific pages provided in the text.

Context:
The text provides information on how to apply for admissions at George Brown College, specifically for domestic and international students. Here are the factual details extracted from the text:

1. International students should visit the "International Admissions" page for country-specific admission requirements.
2. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges.
3. International students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
4. Information sessions are held on a regular basis, and interested individuals can sign up for an upcoming session.
5. For inquiries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines, or the admissions process, contact the Admissions Office at admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section.
6. For financial aid inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.
7. To make an appointment with an Entry Advisor, please review the frequently asked questions.
8. For general inquiries related to programs offered at the Centre for Business, contact business@georgebrown.ca or call (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160.
9. For inquiries related to the International Business Management (B411) program, contact Philip Eng, Program Co-ordinator, at peng@georgebrown.ca.
10. Contact one of George Brown College's international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
11. Visit the campus for more information about the location of the school.

There is no specific mention of the program offered by the college in the text.

Context: The program offered is International Business Management AND Strategically Relationship Marketing. It falls under the School of Management and the classes usually take place at the St. James Campus, specifically at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. The campus tours and info sessions can be booked through the website. Related programs include Project Management (Postgraduate) (B415), Human Resources Management (Postgraduate) (B408), and Financial Planning (Postgraduate) (B407). Carlos Carli is a graduate of this program. The college offers opportunities for students to develop professional skills through roles such as Peer Coach and Marketing Coordinator for the Career Services Centre during co-op terms. Prospective applicants can sign up to receive tailored resources and learn more about their options, programs, and life at George Brown College by providing their first name, last name, email, domestic or international status, and country on the website.
